instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
first post ... please be gentle (my hair is already very grey).

I am trying to repair a mac air mid 2013 with an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> B logic board.   Wine spill on right hand side of keyboard.  

some noticeable corrosion gunk on the board but all looked rather old; so probably predated the recent spill.  no noticeable liquid residue on the SMC side of the board

the liquid damage tell-tale under the lcd connector was bright red.  There was some gunk on the connector itself and the pins, but no pad damage, and no evident burning.  

Fuse F7770 was burned out, and the cap next to it (<CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>) was crisped on one side but still measuring 100nF.  so light cooked rather than cindered. I've removed it for the time being anyway. 

green light comes on with the charger.  Doesn't turn orange but no battery connected. I've fluxed up the SMC and given it some heat.  only to about 140C though.  

the power rails are as follows:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                     8.2v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>    8.2v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>        8.2v

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>              16.5v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>                   16.5v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>                    3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>                    0.6v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>                       0.5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>                    0.5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>                       1.16v


diode mode measurements to ground
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                     0.131v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>                    0.266v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>                       0.413v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>                    0.576v

nothing gets evidently hot.  the SMC is perhaps 8C above ambient.  

can anyone suggest a diagnosis or steps to take to get closer to one?  I don't have any suitably sized components for swap outs so can't go a trial and error route unfortunately!  

many thanks in advance. 
Justin

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: You are going to need parts. I would start with measuring resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and check the clock chip area and <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> area.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: 8.2 volts on PPBUS means the SMC isn't turning on. Tried a known good flat cable and I/O board? Voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>? After that the clock circuit needs to be addressed need 3.3 volts steady on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="rvanpruissen, post: 33173"]You are going to need parts. I would start with measuring resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and check the clock chip area and <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> area.[/QUOTE]


thanks for the replies.  Appreciate that I will need parts.  Mouser supports my area of france adequately, if not rapidly.

resistance to ground from <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 161.5kOhms

on <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> the voltages are:

pin 1  3.33v
pin 2  0
pin 3  3.3v     //<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_SMC_SPV</SIGNAL>
pin 4  1.8v     //<SIGNAL>SMC_MANUAL_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
pin 5  0.65v   //<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
pin 6  3.26v   //<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL>
pin 7  3.29v   //<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
pin 8  3.29v   //<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AREF_SMC</SIGNAL>


Is it odd that <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is being driven low? It is not shorted to ground (16MOhm or so).  The pull up resistor is good although measuring (in circuit) as 70k rather than 100k.  

i've prodded around some of the clock circuit and nothing seems odd apart from the voltage.  But tbh I'm not sure what I should be checking.  could the clock chip be bust?  


so ...I reflowed the clock chip, and now get the green charger light turning orange after 3 seconds.  so that's an improvement, I guess? 

after reflowing the clock chip I get 8.6v back on PPBUS, 3.42v on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and 1.6v on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

but nothing on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>

so perhaps there was a short under the clock chip, now gone with reflowing but the clock chip is bust? 

advice gratefully received.

thanks
Justin

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: Replace the clock chip as it will have corroded pads under it, same with <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> really. Also remove J6100 to avoid corrosion issues under it.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
I took the clock chip off and checked before reflowing it.  It looked fine.  The original gunk went with the removal.

Would absence of ppvrtc prevent power on?

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: Yes, PPVRTC must absolutely be there. Replace the chip and check again.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
Thanks Duke

parts ordered so I'll report back when they're on the board.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: Good question!  This is in the pile of things to do.  I will try to resurrect it tomorrow and report back.
